resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

components.name: Integration
components.description: Issues related to integration / compatibility tests between implementations

lihalite commented on pull request #4905: ARROW-5978: [FlightRPC] [Java] Properly release buffers in Flight integration client
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4905
 
 
   Fixes a bug where dictionaries weren't properly released in cleaning up a flight stream.
   
   Travis build: https://travis-ci.com/lihalite/arrow/builds/119663270

lihalite commented on issue #4905: ARROW-5978: [FlightRPC] [Java] Properly release buffers in Flight integration client
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4905#issuecomment-513202680
 
 
   Ah sorry, I got distracted - this exposed another bug in the Java integration server, which I've been digging into (dictionaries don't get sent back to the client, the client just gets an empty dictionary). I'll close this for now.

lihalite commented on pull request #4913: ARROW-5978: [FlightRPC] [Java] Properly release buffers in Flight integration client URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4913#discussion_r305480977 ########## File path: java/flight/src/main/java/org/apache/arrow/flight/FlightStream.java ########## @@ -95,10 +95,30 @@ public Schema getSchema() { return schema; } + /** + * Get the provider for dictionaries in this stream. + * + *

Does NOT retain a reference to the underlying dictionaries. Dictionaries may be updated as the stream is read. + * + * @see #retainDictionaries() + */ public DictionaryProvider getDictionaryProvider() { return dictionaries; } + /** + * Retain a reference to each of the dictionaries in the stream. Should be called after finishing reading the stream, + * but before closing. + * + * @return The current dictionaries in the stream. + */ + public DictionaryProvider retainDictionaries() { Review comment: We have to swap out the entire provider, rather than just retaining a reference to the underlying buffers, as closing a FieldVector also clears it. ---------------------------------------------------------------- This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service. To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the URL above to go to the specific comment. For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at: users@infra.apache.org

lihalite commented on pull request #4913: ARROW-5978: [FlightRPC] [Java] Properly release buffers in Flight integration client URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4913#discussion_r305480388 ########## File path: java/flight/src/main/java/org/apache/arrow/flight/FlightStream.java ########## @@ -95,10 +95,30 @@ public Schema getSchema() { return schema; } + /** + * Get the provider for dictionaries in this stream. + * + *

Does NOT retain a reference to the underlying dictionaries. Dictionaries may be updated as the stream is read. + * + * @see #retainDictionaries() + */ public DictionaryProvider getDictionaryProvider() { return dictionaries; } + /** + * Retain a reference to each of the dictionaries in the stream. Should be called after finishing reading the stream, + * but before closing. + * + * @return The current dictionaries in the stream. + */ + public DictionaryProvider retainDictionaries() { Review comment: Not the happiest with this API or implementation; open to suggestions. ---------------------------------------------------------------- This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service. To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the URL above to go to the specific comment. For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at: users@infra.apache.org

lihalite commented on pull request #4913: ARROW-5978: [FlightRPC] [Java] Properly release buffers in Flight integration client
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4913#discussion_r305480555
 
 

 ##########
 File path: java/flight/src/main/java/org/apache/arrow/flight/FlightStream.java
 ##########
 @@ -117,8 +137,12 @@ public void close() throws Exception {
         .map(t -> ((AutoCloseable) t))
         .collect(Collectors.toList());
 
+    final List<FieldVector> dictionaryVectors = dictionaries.getDictionaryIds().stream()
 
 Review comment:
   Might it be worth factoring out some sort of `closeDictionaries`? I've written something like this a couple times now.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

lihalite commented on pull request #4913: ARROW-5978: [FlightRPC] [Java] Properly release buffers in Flight integration client
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4913#discussion_r305480749
 
 

 ##########
 File path: java/flight/src/main/java/org/apache/arrow/flight/FlightStream.java
 ##########
 @@ -117,8 +137,12 @@ public void close() throws Exception {
         .map(t -> ((AutoCloseable) t))
         .collect(Collectors.toList());
 
+    final List<FieldVector> dictionaryVectors = dictionaries.getDictionaryIds().stream()
 
 Review comment:
   The caveat with doing it here is that you have to remember to keep the dictionaries alive if you want to use the data beyond the stream lifetime.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

emkornfield commented on pull request #4913: ARROW-5978: [FlightRPC] [Java] Properly release buffers in Flight integration client URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4913#discussion_r312774204 ########## File path: java/flight/src/main/java/org/apache/arrow/flight/FlightStream.java ########## @@ -95,10 +95,30 @@ public Schema getSchema() { return schema; } + /** + * Get the provider for dictionaries in this stream. + * + *

Does NOT retain a reference to the underlying dictionaries. Dictionaries may be updated as the stream is read. + * + * @see #retainDictionaries() + */ public DictionaryProvider getDictionaryProvider() { return dictionaries; } + /** + * Retain a reference to each of the dictionaries in the stream. Should be called after finishing reading the stream, + * but before closing. + * + * @return The current dictionaries in the stream. + */ + public DictionaryProvider retainDictionaries() { Review comment: I'm just ramping up on the Java dictionary stuff so I apologize if these are silly questions: Would it make sense to have dictionaryprovider have some mode where it handles retention? and maybe rename this to transferDictionaries(). This actually looks like it does the opposite of retention (it looks like it removes a reference? ---------------------------------------------------------------- This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service. lihalite commented on pull request #4913: ARROW-5978: [FlightRPC] [Java] Properly release buffers in Flight integration client URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4913#discussion_r312891985 ########## File path: java/flight/src/main/java/org/apache/arrow/flight/FlightStream.java ########## @@ -95,10 +95,30 @@ public Schema getSchema() { return schema; } + /** + * Get the provider for dictionaries in this stream. + * + *

Does NOT retain a reference to the underlying dictionaries. Dictionaries may be updated as the stream is read. + * + * @see #retainDictionaries() + */ public DictionaryProvider getDictionaryProvider() { return dictionaries; } + /** + * Retain a reference to each of the dictionaries in the stream. Should be called after finishing reading the stream, + * but before closing. + * + * @return The current dictionaries in the stream. + */ + public DictionaryProvider retainDictionaries() { Review comment: Yes, this API is rather confusing :/ there is a corresponding method that gets a reference to the provider, and this method removes this object's reference without decrementing the ref count, so that when this object is closed, it won't decrement the ref count or do any other cleanup. Unfortunately, we can't just have this method increment the ref count for you, because the close() implementation for dictionaries also clears the underlying buffers. The DictionaryProvider API is rather sparse: there was more than one time where I wanted to be able to iterate all the dictionaries, but you can't do that directly. I think there's been long-running discussion for improving the Java dictionary APIs, maybe this is another point to clear up. ---------------------------------------------------------------- This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service. issuetype.description: A new unit, integration or system test.
issuetype.name: Test

fields.description:
The integration test client doesn't close any of the clients or free any of the buffers it creates.

Trying to do so leads to a leak problem on the dictionary vector case.
fields.summary: [FlightRPC] [Java] Integration test client doesn't close buffers
